“Back to the Future,” opening tonight on Broadway, is a nearly scene-by-scene re-creation of the 1985 movie on which it’s based. The Book of Mormon is that rarest of Broadway commodities: a new musical that's both hilariously funny and toe-tappingly entertaining, while also being smart, sophisticated, and surprisingly sweet.
The Bottom Line: The first Broadway musical from the “South Park” team will have the comedy faithful flocking.

What's perhaps less expected is that while The Book of Mormon packs plenty of blissful profanity, sacrilege and politically incorrect mischief, the defining quality of this hugely entertaining show is its sweetness.

The most remarkable thing about the new musical, “How to Dance in Ohio,” is not that it features seven autistic actors as its stars, although that’s a Broadway first. There’s a refreshingly communal spirit in Water for Elephants, a new musical based on Sara Gruen’s novel which just opened at the Imperial Theatre under Jessica Stone’s connective direction.

Water for Elephants is a sweeping spectacle that manages to capture both the grandeur and intimacy of Sara Gruen's beloved novel. The production succeeds in creating theatrical magic through stunning puppetry and heartfelt performances.
